problems.title: Gamma Distribution Sum Property
problems.description: Prove that the sum of independent gamma random variables follows a gamma distribution
problems.problem:
If \(X_i\) are independently distributed according to \(\Gamma(\alpha_i,b)\), show that \(\sum X_i\) is distributed as \(\Gamma(\sum \alpha_i,b)\).

Hint: Method 1. Prove it first for the sum of two gamma variables by a transformation to \(Y_1=X_1+X_2\), \(Y_2=X_1/X_2\), and then use induction.

problems.title: Causal Inference with OLS Prediction Models
problems.description: Show properties of OLS estimators in treatment effect estimation
problems.problem:
Assume we are given a data set \((Z_i, X_i, Y_i)_{i=1}^n\). Using data only from the treatment group \(\{i : Z_i = 1\}\), we can build an OLS prediction model for \(Y\):
$$\hat{\mu}_1(x) = \hat{\gamma}_1 + \hat{\beta}_1^{\top} x$$

More precisely,
$$(\hat{\beta}_1, \hat{\gamma}_1) = \arg\min_{\beta_1, \gamma_1} \sum_{i: Z_i=1} (Y_i - \gamma_1 - \beta_1^{\top} X_i)^2$$

Similarly, using data only from the control group \(\{i : Z_i = 0\}\), we can train an OLS model for \(Y\):
$$\hat{\mu}_0(x) = \hat{\gamma}_0 + \hat{\beta}_0^{\top} x$$

Using these predictions, form the following estimator:
$$\hat{\tau}_{pred} = \frac{1}{n} \left( \sum_{i: Z_i=1} Y_i + \sum_{i: Z_i=0} \hat{\mu}_1(X_i) - \sum_{i: Z_i=1} \hat{\mu}_0(X_i) - \sum_{i: Z_i=0} Y_i \right)$$

Using properties of ordinary least-squares, show that:
1. \(\hat{\gamma}_1 = \frac{1}{n_1} \sum_{i: Z_i=1} (Y_i - \hat{\beta}_1^{\top} X_i)\)
2. Use this to show \(\sum_{i: Z_i=1} Y_i = \sum_{i: Z_i=1} \hat{\mu}_1(X_i)\)
3. Similarly, show that \(\sum_{i: Z_i=0} Y_i = \sum_{i: Z_i=0} \hat{\mu}_0(X_i)\)
